items.title: White House confirms 2nd strike on alleged drug boat, denies Hegseth ordered it
items.standfirst: White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt on Monday confirmed Washington Post reporting that the U.S. launched two strikes on an alleged drug boat in September, but denied Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered the second strike that killed two survivors of the initial attack. CBS News senior White House and political correspondent Ed O'Keefe reports. Then, Jamil Jaffer, former associate counsel to President George W. Bush, joins with analysis.

items.title: Bipartisan US lawmakers launch probes into follow-up strike on alleged drug boat
items.standfirst: Lawmakers from both sides of the aisle have called for investigations after the Washington Post reported that US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered all crew members to be killed in a double strike on suspected drug traffickers. The Trump administration's campaign of launching maritime strikes on alleged drug boats has so far killed more than 80 people.

items.title: Venezuela: Hegseth allegedly ordered ‘kill everybody’ in second drug boat strike
items.standfirst: According to The Washington Post, US forces carried out a follow-up strike on a suspected Venezuelan drug boat in September after seeing two survivors of an initial strike clinging to the burning vessel. The report said US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had ordered troops to "kill everybody" on board the vessel – a claim Hegseth dismissed as "fake news".
items.content: According to The Washington Post, US forces carried out a follow-up strike on a suspected Venezuelan drug boat in September after seeing two survivors of an initial strike clinging to the burning vessel. The report said US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had ordered troops to "kill everybody" on board the vessel – a claim Hegseth dismissed as "fake news".

items.standfirst: President Trump's special envoy, Steve Witkoff, is headed to Russia for peace talks with Vladimir Putin. The trip comes after negotiations were held with Ukrainian officials in Florida over the weekend. Meanwhile, Russian missiles and drones continue to bombard Ukrainian cities. CBS News intelligence and national security reporter Olivia Gazis has more.

items.title: US-Russia talks may pile pressure on Kyiv to make concessions, says EU foreign policy chief
items.standfirst: Kaja Kallas says negotiators should not ‘lose focus that it’s actually Russia who has started this war’Europe live – latest updatesThe EU’s foreign policy chief, Kaja Kallas, has said she fears talks between the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and Donald Trump’s special envoy, Steve Witkoff, will pile pressure on Ukraine to make concessions with the two men expected to meet on Tuesday.Witkoff, the property developer turned envoy recently exposed for coaching Russian officials on how to win Trump’s favour, is arriving in Moscow after leading a US delegation in talks with Ukraine at the weekend, nearly four years after Russia launched its full-scale invasion. Continue reading...
items.content: Kaja Kallas says negotiators should not ‘lose focus that it’s actually Russia who has started this war’Europe live – latest updatesThe EU’s foreign policy chief, Kaja Kallas, has said she fears talks between the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and Donald Trump’s special envoy, Steve Witkoff, will pile pressure on Ukraine to make concessions with the two men expected to meet on Tuesday.Witkoff, the property developer turned envoy recently exposed for coaching Russian officials on how to win Trump’s favour, is arriving in Moscow after leading a US delegation in talks with Ukraine at the weekend, nearly four years after Russia launched its full-scale invasion. items.title: Zipcar, world’s biggest car-sharing company, to close UK operation
items.standfirst: Move by firm, owned by US group Avis Budget, will remove access to shared fleet across London at end of yearThe world’s biggest car-sharing company, Zipcar, has said it will close its UK operation, removing access to its shared fleet across London at the end of this year.The company, owned by the US car rental group Avis Budget, said it would suspend new bookings through its app after 31 December, pending the outcome of a consultation on possible redundancies. The UK operating company had 71 staff last year, according to its latest accounts. Continue reading...

items.title: Macron calls for Europeans to have a seat at the table in Ukraine negotiations
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron and his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky launched a flurry of diplomatic activity during hours-long talks at the Élysée Palace in Paris on Monday. Macron said he hoped that ongoing talks around ending the war in Ukraine could be a "turning point" for both the Ukrainians and Europe's own security situation.

items.title: Macron - Zelensky: ‘No peace deal without Ukraine and Europe’
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky gave a joint address on Monday, speaking about peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia. Zelensky notably stated that Russia must not be rewarded for its invasion in February 2022. #emmanuelmacron #VolodymyrZelensky #ukraine
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky gave a joint address on Monday, speaking about peace negotiations between Ukraine and Russia. items.title: Intense diplomacy in Paris as Macron and Zelensky seek consensus on peace plan
items.standfirst: As Emmanuel Macron and Volodymyr Zelensky jointly addressed the public regarding peace negotiations in Ukraine, FRANCE 24's senior journalist Catherine Norris Trent reports that diplomatic activity at the Élysée appears intense. Numerous delegates are working to secure as much support as possible in a short time, aiming to persuade both the United States and Russia to back a peace plan that is more acceptable than the 28-point proposal put forward by the US a few days ago, especially on security guarantees.
items.content: As Emmanuel Macron and Volodymyr Zelensky jointly addressed the public regarding peace negotiations in Ukraine, FRANCE 24's senior journalist Catherine Norris Trent reports that diplomatic activity at the Élysée appears intense. Numerous delegates are working to secure as much support as possible in a short time, aiming to persuade both the United States and Russia to back a peace plan that is more acceptable than the 28-point proposal put forward by the US a few days ago, especially on security guarantees.

items.title: High-stakes Ukraine diplomacy intensifies as Zelensky is in Paris
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky met French President Emmanuel Macron in Paris on Monday to reinforce European support for Ukraine at a potentially pivotal moment in Kyiv’s battle against the Russian invasion. The talks, held inside the Elysée Palace, come as Washington pushes a plan to end the war. For FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris Trent, the choice of words and phrasing by both leaders in their upcoming joint speech is worth paying attention to.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky met French President Emmanuel Macron in Paris on Monday to reinforce European support for Ukraine at a potentially pivotal moment in Kyiv’s battle against the Russian invasion. The talks, held inside the Elysée Palace, come as Washington pushes a plan to end the war. For FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris Trent, the choice of words and phrasing by both leaders in their upcoming joint speech is worth paying attention to.

ai_summary: Ukrainian President Zelensky praised a new peace plan iteration.
Zelensky met with French President Macron in Paris.
Macron called for European involvement in Ukraine negotiations.
Zelensky stated Russia must not be rewarded for its invasion.
Diplomatic activity in Paris appears intense regarding the peace plan.

items.title: Pope urges unity at gathering of Muslim and Christian leaders in Beirut
items.standfirst: Religious leaders at an interfaith assembly with Pope Leo XIV on Monday emphasised the importance of unity and coexistence in Beirut's Martyrs' Square, which once embodied Lebanon's sectarian strife. While the country's political system is based on religious equity, the country has nevertheless suffered years of sectarian conflict.

clusters.title: Spain busts neo-Nazi group on international terror lists
clusters.neutral_headline: Spain Busts Neo-Nazi Group Listed as Terrorist Organization
bullet_summary: "The Base" operates through an international network of paramilitary cells with the aim of perpetrating attacks and preparing for a "race war," police said
Reported by France24, CBS News

items.title: Spain busts neo-Nazi group on international terror lists
items.standfirst: Spanish police on Monday said they had broken up a cell of "The Base", a transnational neo-Nazi white supremacist group designated a terrorist organisation by the European Union, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. The US-founded movement operates through a decentralised, international network of paramilitary cells with the aim of perpetrating attacks and preparing for a "race war", the police said in a statement. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell reports.
items.content: Spanish police on Monday said they had broken up a cell of "The Base", a transnational neo-Nazi white supremacist group designated a terrorist organisation by the European Union, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. The US-founded movement operates through a decentralised, international network of paramilitary cells with the aim of perpetrating attacks and preparing for a "race war", the police said in a statement. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell reports.

ai_summary: Spanish police dismantled a cell of "The Base," a neo-Nazi group.

Their aim is to perpetrate attacks and prepare for a "race war."

clusters.title: Asia floods death toll tops 1,160 as troops aid survivors
clusters.neutral_headline: Asia Floods Death Toll Exceeds 1,160, Military Aids
bullet_summary: Officials said the extent of the damage in the country’s worst-affected central region was slowly becoming clear on Sunday as relief workers cleared roads blocked by fallen trees and mudslides
Reported by France24, Guardian World

items.title: Asia floods death toll tops 1,160 as troops aid survivors
items.standfirst: The toll in deadly flooding and landslides across parts of Asia climbed past 1,160 on Monday as hardest-hit Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed military personnel to help survivors. Speaking with FRANCE 24's Mark Owen, Dr Akshay Deoras, Research Scientist at the National Centre for Atmospheric Science at the University of Reading, says that 'the focus has to shift from talking about climate change to really dealing with it on the ground and keep people away from vulnerable areas'.
items.content: The toll in deadly flooding and landslides across parts of Asia climbed past 1,160 on Monday as hardest-hit Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed military personnel to help survivors. Speaking with FRANCE 24's Mark Owen, Dr Akshay Deoras, Research Scientist at the National Centre for Atmospheric Science at the University of Reading, says that 'the focus has to shift from talking about climate change to really dealing with it on the ground and keep people away from vulnerable areas'.

items.title: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100
items.standfirst: Millions of people affected by torrential rainfall in Sri Lanka and large parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, southern Thailand and northern MalaysiaHow cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideSri Lanka and Indonesia have deployed military personnel as they race to help victims of devastating flooding that has killed more than 1,100 people across four countries in Asia.Millions of people have been affected by a combination of tropical cyclones and heavy monsoon rains in Sri Lanka, parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, Thailand and Malaysia in recent days. Continue reading...
items.content: Millions of people affected by torrential rainfall in Sri Lanka and large parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, southern Thailand and northern MalaysiaHow cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideSri Lanka and Indonesia have deployed military personnel as they race to help victims of devastating flooding that has killed more than 1,100 people across four countries in Asia.Millions of people have been affected by a combination of tropical cyclones and heavy monsoon rains in Sri Lanka, parts of Indonesia’s Sumatra, Thailand and Malaysia in recent days. Continue reading...

items.title: Death toll passes 1,100 in devastating floods across Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Malaysia and Thailand – as it happened
items.standfirst: This blog is now closed.Full report: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100How cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideCyclone Ditwah, which unleashed catastrophic flooding and landslides across Sri Lanka, has brought heavy rain to India’s southern state of Tamil Nadu.The storm, now about 30 miles off the coast of the city of Chennai, the state capital, has weakened into a “deep depression”, according to weather officials, who expect it to weaken even further across the day. Continue reading...
items.content: This blog is now closed.Full report: Sri Lanka and Indonesia deploy militaries as Asia floods death toll passes 1,100How cyclones and monsoon rains combined to devastate parts of Asia – visual guideCyclone Ditwah, which unleashed catastrophic flooding and landslides across Sri Lanka, has brought heavy rain to India’s southern state of Tamil Nadu.The storm, now about 30 miles off the coast of the city of Chennai, the state capital, has weakened into a “deep depression”, according to weather officials, who expect it to weaken even further across the day. items.title: Sri Lanka braced for more damage after torrential rain kills hundreds across Asia
items.standfirst: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in USMore heavy rainfall is expected in Sri Lanka in the coming days, likely resulting in further damage across the country. It comes after torrential rainfall in south-east Asia triggered catastrophic flash floods and landslides that have affected millions, killing more than 300 people in Indonesia and 160 in Thailand, with hundreds more still missing.Parts of North Sumatra, Indonesia, were hit with rainfall totals of 800mm over four days, with other areas also experiencing heavy rainfall. Continue reading...
items.content: Meanwhile, Iran grapples with one of worst droughts and temperatures fall 10C below normal in USMore heavy rainfall is expected in Sri Lanka in the coming days, likely resulting in further damage across the country. It comes after torrential rainfall in south-east Asia triggered catastrophic flash floods and landslides that have affected millions, killing more than 300 people in Indonesia and 160 in Thailand, with hundreds more still missing.Parts of North Sumatra, Indonesia, were hit with rainfall totals of 800mm over four days, with other areas also experiencing heavy rainfall. Continue reading...

items.title: Death toll passes 900 in Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka floods
items.standfirst: Officials in Indonesia say more than 442 people have died, while Sri Lanka suffers worst natural disaster since 2004 tsunami Authorities in Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Thailand are racing to clear debris and find hundreds of missing people after more than 900 died in devastating floods and landslides across the south of Asia.In the latest example of the impact of the climate crisis on storm patterns and extreme weather, heavy monsoon rains, exacerbated by a tropical storm, have overwhelmed parts of south-east Asia in recent days, leaving thousands of people stranded without shelter or critical supplies. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials in Indonesia say more than 442 people have died, while Sri Lanka suffers worst natural disaster since 2004 tsunami Authorities in Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Thailand are racing to clear debris and find hundreds of missing people after more than 900 died in devastating floods and landslides across the south of Asia.In the latest example of the impact of the climate crisis on storm patterns and extreme weather, heavy monsoon rains, exacerbated by a tropical storm, have overwhelmed parts of south-east Asia in recent days, leaving thousands of people stranded without shelter or critical supplies. Continue reading...

items.title: Sri Lanka’s capital hit by floods as cyclone death toll nears 200
items.standfirst: Hundreds of people still missing after heavy rain and mudslides in country’s deadliest natural disaster for yearsEntire areas of Sri Lanka’s capital are flooded after a powerful cyclone triggered heavy rains and mudslides across the island, with authorities reporting nearly 200 dead and dozens more missing.Officials said the extent of the damage in the country’s worst-affected central region was slowly becoming clear on Sunday as relief workers cleared roads blocked by fallen trees and mudslides. Continue reading...
items.content: Hundreds of people still missing after heavy rain and mudslides in country’s deadliest natural disaster for yearsEntire areas of Sri Lanka’s capital are flooded after a powerful cyclone triggered heavy rains and mudslides across the island, with authorities reporting nearly 200 dead and dozens more missing.Officials said the extent of the damage in the country’s worst-affected central region was slowly becoming clear on Sunday as relief workers cleared roads blocked by fallen trees and mudslides. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Flooding and landslides in Asia have caused over 1,160 deaths.
Sri Lanka and Indonesia deployed military personnel to assist survivors.
Millions of people have been affected by the extreme weather.
The flooding was caused by cyclones and heavy monsoon rains.
A scientist suggests shifting focus to climate change solutions.

clusters.title: OBR chair quits after inquiry into early release of budget document
clusters.neutral_headline: OBR Chair Resigns After Budget Document Leak
bullet_summary: The departure of Richard Hughes, who said he took “full responsibility” for the watchdog’s failure to handle sensitive information, dragged the rolling recriminations over the budget into a fifth day
Reported by Guardian World, Guardian Business

items.title: OBR chair quits after inquiry into early release of budget document
items.standfirst: Richard Hughes takes ‘full responsibility’ for watchdog error as Starmer attempts to secure chancellor’s positionThe chair of the Office for Budget Responsibility has resigned after a damning internal inquiry into the leak that threw Rachel Reeves’s budget into chaos described it as the “worst failure” in the institution’s history.The departure of Richard Hughes, who said he took “full responsibility” for the watchdog’s failure to handle sensitive information, dragged the rolling recriminations over the budget into a fifth day. Continue reading...
items.content: Richard Hughes takes ‘full responsibility’ for watchdog error as Starmer attempts to secure chancellor’s positionThe chair of the Office for Budget Responsibility has resigned after a damning internal inquiry into the leak that threw Rachel Reeves’s budget into chaos described it as the “worst failure” in the institution’s history.The departure of Richard Hughes, who said he took “full responsibility” for the watchdog’s failure to handle sensitive information, dragged the rolling recriminations over the budget into a fifth day. Continue reading...

items.title: OBR says inadvertent budget leak is ‘worst failure’ in its 15-year history
items.standfirst: Investigation finds organisation’s leadership over many years was to blame for error, and similar breach happened earlier this yearPolitics live –latest updatesBritain’s budget watchdog has said the early leak of its budget documents before Rachel Reeves made her speech was the “worst failure” in its 15-year history as it emerged a similar breach had occurred earlier this year.The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) said an investigation had found that the leadership of the organisation, over many years, was to blame for the early release of its Economic and Fiscal Outlook (EFO) document online nearly an hour before Reeves’s address last Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Investigation finds organisation’s leadership over many years was to blame for error, and similar breach happened earlier this yearPolitics live –latest updatesBritain’s budget watchdog has said the early leak of its budget documents before Rachel Reeves made her speech was the “worst failure” in its 15-year history as it emerged a similar breach had occurred earlier this year.The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) said an investigation had found that the leadership of the organisation, over many years, was to blame for the early release of its Economic and Fiscal Outlook (EFO) document online nearly an hour before Reeves’s address last Wednesday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Office for Budget Responsibility chair resigned after an inquiry.
The inquiry investigated the early release of budget documents.
The leak was described as the "worst failure" in the OBR's history.
Richard Hughes took responsibility for the handling of information.
A similar breach occurred earlier in the year, according to the OBR.
